chemical_disease_relation_menu.desc: The chemical has some type of relation to the disease.

children.desc: The chemical worsens or exacerbates the disease in any manner.
The chemical improves or treats the disease in any manner.

Symptoms are defined as subjective physical or mental manifestations of a disease; examples include stomachache, lower-back pain, and fatigue. Signs are defined as objective manifestations of a disease; examples include high white blood cell count or bloody stool.
Causes of disease include infectious, non-communicable/non-transferable, or lifestyle causes.
children.example: Artificial tears improve dry and itchy eyes in alacrima patients.

children.desc: Administration of the drug increases chances of getting the disease. Considered an 'adverse side effect' of the drug.
children.example: Parkinson's disease risk factors include ageing, exposure to toxins and genetic defects.

children.desc: Administration of the chemical may cause or lead to the disease.
children.example: 43% of mice given the chemical NVP-BHG712 developed pulmonary metastases.

children.desc: Administration of the chemical prevents the disease
children.example: Here, we demonstrate for the first time that treatment with gingerol prevents prion peptide-mediated neuronal cell death. This study suggests that treatment with gingerol may provide a novel therapeutic strategy for prion-mediated neurotoxicity

chemical_disease_relation_menu.desc: There is no relation between the chemical and disease.
chemical_disease_relation_menu.example: To study soft tissue sarcoma, an experimental group of mice was given the chemical NVP-BHG712.

gene_disease_relation_menu.desc: The gene is related to the disease in some manner.
gene_disease_relation_menu.example: The gene responsible for Triple A syndrome, AAAS, has recently been identified.

children.desc: Gene expression is the process by which information from a gene is used in the synthesis of a functional gene product (mRNA, protein, or microRNAs). When gene expression is altered, gene expression is either increased or decreased.
children.example: Several studies revealed significantly higher EPHB4 expression in malignancies such as prostate cancer and colorectal cancer.

children.desc: Gene mutations or aberrations are permanent changes in the gene DNA sequence, differing from the sequence found in most people. Mutations range in size; they can affect anywhere from a single DNA base pair to a large piece of a chromosome that includes multiple genes.
children.example: Mutations in the COL5A or COL3A genes are only a few of the genetic causes of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

children.text: And post-translational modifications are associated with
children.desc: Translation is protein synthesis. When changes are made to a protein during or after translation, it is considered a post-translational modification.
children.example: A small interfering RNA causes knockdown of ATP2C1 expression, resulting in defects in both post-translational processing of wild-type thyroglobulin

gene_disease_relation_menu.desc: The gene does not relate to the disease.
